title.narrative: Strengthening protected areas in southern Tanzania

description.narrative: Strengthening the Protected Area Network in Southern Tanzania: Improving the Effectiveness of National Parks in Addressing Threats to Biodiversity.

title.narrative: Strengthening the protected area network in Southern Tanzania
WALKING SAFARI GUIDE TRAINING REPORT NOV 2013 2 2
Strengthening protected areas in southern Tanzania
Strengthening protected areas in southern Tanzania
Strengthening protected areas in southern Tanzania

description.narrative: Increase effectiveness of National Parks in protecting biodiversity and provide for long-term ecological, social and financial sustainability
independent political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration
The biodiversity of Southern Tanzania is better represented and buffered from threat within National Parks. (GEF 5.3 mill USD)

No net loss of natural habitat in major habitat blocks identified as critical for wildlife dispersal. Two large habitat blocks (Greater Ruaha Landscape and Greater-Kitulo-Kipengere Landscape) are secured with functioning corridors

comment.narrative: Within the GRL, TANAPA have management plans for RUNAPA; WCS and local government supporting development of Mbomipa and Umemaruwa WMAs. In GKKL, KINAPA, MKGR and MRNR have management plans.

A working model for integrating management of NPs and wider productive landscapes is operationalised; secures wildlife corridors and dispersal areas covering over 39,000 km2 in the GRL and GKKL ecological landscapes.

The project collaborated with KNP and Busokelo District Council to introduce a technology on energy-efficient stoves in 10 villages within the council which also border KNP in order to reduce pressure on KNP from the villages for fuel-wood. The 3 PAs were also supported to undertake fair and open processes towards clearing and demarcating their boundaries hence improving relations with their respective neighbouring communities.
Furthermore the project collaborated with KNP and Busokelo District Council to train 46 local artisans from 10 villages in the council which also border KNP, on installation of energy-efficient stoves. This technology is cheap and it is expected that the villages will adopt it easily hence reducing pressure from the villages on fuel-wood from KNP.
The Ruaha Roundtable Forum which brings together researchers from within the project area has continues meeting regularly to share findings, challenges and future plans of the respective researches. Information and experiences shared in this forum are enhancing ecological monitoring and addressing threats to biodiversity within and beyond the project area.

description.narrative: Two national parks (RUNAPA and KNP)and one game reserve (MKGR) have increased operational capacity to manage themselves sustainably

comment.narrative: RUNAPA and KNP lack operational capacity to manage park operations and poaching is common; MKGR is in a vulnerable state of management and all three PAs open to risks of fire and poaching

Core NP operations strengthened in Southern Tanzania covering over 22,000 km2 leading to the effective detection and deterrence of poaching and fire risks and improved relationships with adjacent communities.

The project continued implementing planned activities that focus on achieving integrated management of PAs and the wider landscapes. Operationalization of some of the planned working groups has given strong indication of success.
A range of activities were carried out during the reporting period to increase operational capacity of the three core Protected Areas to manage them sustainably.
The motor grader donated by UNDP through the project to RUNAPA has so far accomplished 952 km of roadwork in the park hence significantly improving mobility and accessibility inside the park. Whereas the three anti-poaching vehicles donated in a similar arrangement to RUNAPA (2) and KNP (1) have maintained good working condition and constantly deployed in the field hence contributing significantly to day-to-day protection activities in the PAs. The project has also facilitated procurement of walking safaris gears for RUNAPA. A state-of-the art digital radio communication system is being installed in RUNAPA and will greatly enhance monitoring of law enforcement and ecology activities when complete.
A consultancy to install a radio collaring and monitoring system for thirty (30) Elephants in the GRL is already on progress. Operationalization of the monitoring system is expected to give important insights into Elephants daily and seasonal activity patterns hence informing future strategies to conserve them and their habitats.
The project has collaborated with TANAPA to set up a GIS Unit at RUNAPA. Thanks to TANAPA hq for committing a full time GIS technician to Ruaha to man the centre. The unit will enhance RUNAPAs and other PAs capacity to collect, store and retrieve data for management use. Staff from RUNAPA, KNP and MKGR was part of the beneficiaries from the GIS and Remote Sensing training organized by the project. These will further facilitate operationalization of the GIS Unit.

description.narrative: METT scores are improved in the 4 target PAs, especially RUNAPA, KNP and MKGR.

comment.narrative: Current METT scores as follows: RUNAPA (53), KNP (52), MKGR (21), MRNR (40): average: 42
RUNAPA and KNP both scoring at least 60. An increase in METT scores in MKGR and MRNR to at least 50; monitoring indicates species diversity either unaffected or increased.

Midterm Review results have revealed significant improvement in METT scores for the 4 target PAs as follows; RUNAPA (66), KNP (61), MKGR (49), MRNR (52). Implying RUNAPA, KNP and MRNR have already surpassed their respective projected end-of-the-project minimum METT scores whereas MKGR has missed out its predetermined end-of-project METT score by 1.
x

description.narrative: Integrating management of NPs and broader landscapes in Southern Tanzania
Biodiversity management in NPs, GRs, NRs, wildlife migration corridors and dispersal areas is factored into decision-making governing land use management.

comment.narrative: Management activities are carried out on WMA, district, regional government and TANAPA level but with a lack of a landscape level coordination mechanism

Inter-sectoral District land management coordination mechanism is emplaced in the GRL and GKKL in Southern Tanzania. Management actions evidenced as a result of decisions and support of landscape level committees and working groups functioning beneath them (land use planning unit, ecological monitoring unit, tourism unit, community conservation unit and enforcement unit)

The motor grader for RUNAPA by UNDP through the project and has so far accomplished 952 km of roadwork in the park, significantly improving mobility and accessibility inside the park. The three anti-poaching vehicles donated in a similar arrangement to RUNAPA (2) and KNP (1) have continued being in good working condition and constantly deployed in the field hence contributing significantly to day-to-day protection activities in the PAs. The project has also facilitated procurement of walking safaris gears for RUNAPA.
A consultant was also engaged to install state-of-the art digital radio communication system in RUNAPA. Installation progress is beyond 80%. Among other things, the communication system will be allowing proper linkage of ecological management objectives (such as the monitoring movement of radio- collared elephants) and security management objectives (such as monitoring rangers locations and movements from an operational HQ through LCD screen platforms), The communication system includes 15Solar powered digital VHF High power base stations at Ranger posts and Park HQ, 5 Repeaters Units and Six (6) digital VHF High power vehicle radio units with GPS capability installed and operational in six vehicles.
The consultancy to review governance systems and operational practices in the two project landscapes has been completed and the final report shared amongst relevant stakeholders. Recommendations from the consultancy have greatly informed the process towards formation of the Landscape Coordination Committees.
The project is now finalizing the installation of a digital communication system for Law enforcement in the GRL. With digital hand-held radios, VHF High Power Base Stations and LCD screen monitors, the communication system will greatly improve monitoring of law enforcement and ecological activities in the GRL.
Installation of the Elephant Collaring and Monitoring system which is already underway in the GRL is expected to greatly inform future strategies to conserve and monitor the flagship species, other wildlife species and the general habitat.
The project has collaborated with TANAPA to set up a GIS Unit at RUNAPA that will serve southern National Parks and other PAs. Moreover, a tailor-made training on GIS and Remote Sensing was offered to 26 individuals from TANAPA, WD and District Councils who will work closely with the expert manning the GIS unit in RUNAPA.
The project further supported acquisition of a toll-free mobile number from Vodacom-Tanzania 0800751212 through which good the public can report any poaching information/incidence free of charge. The number has been printed on posters and widely disseminated.

description.narrative: Development impacts in sensitive areas have been mitigated, monitoring and reporting systems are in place, and enforcement measures are operational in GRL and GKKL landscapes.

comment.narrative: Monitoring of species and habitats is managed on an individual PA level; understanding of wildlife corridor functions, species movements and dispersal areas limited.

A systematic conservation plan for both landscapes that balances biodiversity needs, defines wildlife corridors and dispersal areas, with EIA and M&E systems has been ratified, is in use and is informing measures to address threats to biodiversity in core areas and corridors

SPANEST Anti poaching campaigns with local artists resulted in composing of 7 songs the on elephant poaching crisis and local tourism promotion.
Official launching of the songs is under way
The project has collaborated with Iringa District Council to organize and facilitate a visit to the northern Tourist circuit in Arusha and Manyara for the representatives from Malinzanga village Maasai women group. The purpose of the mission was mainly for the group members to observe and learn on relevant cultural activities that could be implemented by the women groups in Malinzanga and project area.
The project has received proposal from Iringa district to collaborate in the development of a women cultural centre at Malinzanga on the route to Ruaha Np. The project intends to set aside some funds to develop the centre in collaboration with the women and the district.

description.narrative: Two specialist units are developed by TANAPA with partners; a land use planning unit and an ecological monitoring unit.

comment.narrative: TANAPA has community conservation service and ecology departments in RUNAPA and KINAPA; however lacking adequate coordination functions with external parties.
TANAPA has the competence and staff skills to lead land use planning, management and monitoring in landscapes

The working groups on the themes of Law Enforcement, Tourism, Community Conservation and Ecological Monitoring (Ruaha Roundtable) continued with their respective operations, enhancing cooperation and coordination amongst stakeholders in the project area. These working groups are diverse, with members from TANAPA, WD, TFS, Regional and District authorities, WMAs, Police and the Private Sector. The community Conservation working group for GRL, with members from RUNAPA, SPANEST, WD and District Councils, collaborated with District Defence and Security Committees to conduct conservation awareness campaign in 11 villages aiming at enhancing the understanding of communities on matters related to wildlife conservation and associated potential benefits in order to gain their support in the fight against degradation of natural resources and poaching.
The operational groups on Law Enforcement, Tourism and Community Conservation are already removing barriers between conservation stakeholders in the project landscapes. For instance the Njombe-Iringa-Mbeya Inter Regional Tourism Committee successful managed to mobilize tourism stakeholders from the southern circuit to participate in Karibu Fair staged annually in Arusha as one team for the first time. The team shared a booth hence provided one-stop information centre for Tanzania Southern Tourist Circuit. The Community Conservation Working group in the GRL which is multi-sectoral worked successfully with District Defense and Security committees to promote conservation awareness in 11 villages bordering the GRL.
Tourism Committees for Njombe, Mbeya and Iringa have formed an inter-region tourism committee that is now overseeing tourism related activities beyond the respective regions confines. This umbrella committee managed to mobilize tourism stakeholders from the southern circuit (both public and private) to participate in Karibu Fair that is staged annually in Arusha bringing in tourism stakeholders from all-over the world. The group shared a stand and managed to promote the Southern Circuit collaboratively. The committee is already working to stage southern circuits own fair in Iringa in 2015.

description.narrative: Relations with neighbouring communities to PAs considerably improved: lower instances of human wildlife conflict, fires and poaching

comment.narrative: TANAPA has community conservation service departments in RUNAPA and KINAPA; however park-community relations remain strained in some crucial border areas.
TANAPA has a staffed community extension services to ensure effective engagement between communities and park authorities and dispute resolution.

TANAPA Community relationship continue to be improved through the engagement of the community representatives in common activities such as meetings, visits and consultations.
Project members participated in a number of official meetings organized by MBOMIPA association
SPANEST Project in collaboration with RUNAPA, Pawaga and Idodi Divisions in Iringa district and the Football Association of Iringa district jointly organized football competitions for the youth representing 21 villages bordering Ruaha National Park.
The aim of the competitions named SPANEST Cup is to bring together the majority of youth from the villages to be educated on the escalating elephant poaching in the park and how the youth could be involved in tackling the crisis. The fact that the majority of the members of the community involved in poaching events are the youth, SPANEST thought for a need to ensure
Over 120 matches involving 21 villages, over 250 youth players, have so far participated in the competitions since the launching of the cup in July 2014 to the current stage of final.
Over 150,000 young men and women and other community members from Idodi and Pawaga divisions (21 villages) participated in the matches and were able to receive a message on the current situation of the elephant poaching in Ruaha and how they could participate to stop it.
The number of people who were involved and educated about the elephant poaching crisis during the two months of the campaign was higher than any public gathering event that anyone would organize.

description.narrative: Public consultations are completed in an open and fair manner; beacons mark PA boundaries clearly

comment.narrative: Recent developments in PA status, especially in western Kitulo area, Mpanga Kipengere and Usangu mean boundaries are not clear; conflicts are a result.
Agreed boundary beacons are in place around three PAs: RUNAPA, KNP and MKGR, including newly gazetted areas such as Usangu.

The project support towards clearance of PAs boundary and installing beacons has been participatory and significant. In RUNAPA a boundary stretch of 100 km which is dispute-free is being cleared and will be followed by installation of 100 four-sided beacons. In KNP a boundary conflict with a neighbouring Mpangala village was resolved in an open and fair manner hence enabling proper demarcation of the village-park shared boundary with 20 drum-size beacons. Further 7 beacons have been installed along the shared boundary between KNP and MRNR. In MKGR awareness meetings on boundary demarcation have been convened in 10 neighbouring villages, in collaboration with respective 3 district authorities (including the District Commissioners). The meetings paved way to clearance of a 60 km boundary stretch.
The Project Unit is already working with WD and other stakeholders for best way forward on the matter as directed by the 4th Project Steering Committee.
RUNAPA collaborated with the Project and Mbarali District Council to undertake Land use Plans in three villages within the district which also border RUNAPA.
This was a follow-up initiative to the training on Land Use Planning and Related Laws for PAs and District Councils staff that was funded by SPANEST and conducted by the National Land Use Planning Commission. The exercise aimed to enable the 3 villages to use their land-based resources sustainably hence reducing pressure on the park. The exercise was further an opportunity for the land use planning-trained staff from RUNAPA, SPANEST and KNP to practise their knowledge and skills.
In FY 2015/16 the project has set funds to implement Land Use Plans in 4 villages within Chamwino district in Dodoma region. The villages border GRL hence the expected output will be reduced pressure on the adjacent PAs caused by encroachment and other unsustainable land uses.
In GKKL the project and KNP involved the Makete District Defence and Security Committee to resolve a boundary conflict between KNP and Mpangala village. The conflict was resolved and the share boundary is already permanently demarcated.

description.narrative: Mpanga Kipengere GR is upgraded to NP through consultative process

comment.narrative: Mpanga Kipengere GR is managed on a meagre budget, fires and poaching are rife; tourism is minimal
Mpanga Kipengere Game Reserve is raised to higher protected area status as a national park
It was determined to not follow up on the Mpanga Kipengere PA status this year. This was assessed in the MTR.

description.narrative: Bujingijila and Numbe valley corridors gazetted

comment.narrative: Wildlife are not able to move from GRL to GKKL , linkages are weak within GKKL PAs
Mpanga Kipengere linked through Numbe valley corridor to Kitulo NP to enable merging the two parks. Bujingijila also allows linkages to Mount Rungwe Nature Reserve

Bujingijila corridor has been secured following survey results showing that the whole area thought to be Bujingijila corridor actually falls within both KNP and MRNR. The 3.2 km long shared boundary of the two PAs along that area has been permanently demarcated with 7 drum-size beacons.
A preliminary survey on Numbe Valley Corridor was conducted by a team comprising staff from Makete District Council, KNP, MKGR and SPANEST. The preliminary survey outcomes included a proposed course of actions to secure the corridor. The proposed course of actions includes awareness meetings to 3 villages adjacent to Numbe valley, facilitating land use plans in the villages and carryout a physical survey. These are included in the budget for 2015/16.

description.narrative: Operations Support for National Park Management in Southern Tanzania
Ranger and staff training programme in existence in RUNAPA and KNP; MKGR has joint TANAPA-WD programme; guide training and documentary programmes in existence.

comment.narrative: Rangers have insufficient capacity in RUNAPA, KNP and MKGR to gather intelligence on poaching and fires; relations with tour operators and tourists often strained because of lack of customer care capacity; lack of value-add services.

Systematic staff training programme covering all aspects of PA operations ensures 300 rangers, guides and other field staff meet appropriate competencies according to skill set e.g. enforcement, community relations, tourism etc.).

The project continued to facilitate trainings for PAs staff and other stakeholders geared towards bridging pre-established knowledge and skill gaps.
TANAPA rangers training to develop a Rapid Response Unit for Ruaha National Park rangers which involved three stage training: Selection, Basic, Paramedics, Commanders, and Intensive training. At the end of the training a team of 37 Rangers successfully completed the training aimed to develop and equip them for rapid response to poaching incidences in the Great Ruaha Landscape. The training was conducted by Aegis Defence Services Limited (Aegis), a UK-based company. The Rapid Response Team is already deployed in RUNAPA whereas TANAPA and the project have further strengthened the team by providing them with patrol equipment and f gears.
During the reporting period, a 56 percent decrease of poaching incidences in Ruaha National Park was reported by TANAPA whereby a total of 36 elephants were killed in the year 2013/2014 compared to 82 elephants in the year 2012/2013.
During the same period TANAPA reported on the Improved average time of rangers patrol deployment by 30% and 54% for Ruaha NP and Kitulo NP respectively through patrol vehicles donated by SPANEST project.
Staff from RUNAPA, KNP and MKGR was part of the participants to tailor-made trainings on GIS and Remote Sensing and Open Performance Review and Appraisal (OPRAS). The training on GIS and Remote Sensing was necessary in order to enhance improved collection, storage and analysis of field data in the PAs and across the project landscapes. The Open Performance Review and Appraisal System (OPRAS) are generally accepted as the best appraisal system around in terms of motivating employees and ultimately enhancing efficiency and effectiveness at working stations. Staff from RUNAPA, KNP and MKGR were trained on OPRAS alongside other project stakeholders in order to enhance staff motivation and hence efficiency in the PAs.
The Village Game Scouts for MBOMIPA WMA were supported uniforms and other field gears by the project in order to strengthen security in this PA which borders RUNAPA.

description.narrative: Finance and business planning has established management costs for different PAs and WMAs, and provides accurate revenue forecasts for each PA and the wider landscape (GRL/GKKL) and matches revenue to priority management needs.

comment.narrative: Business planning in southern Tanzania\\\'s PAs lacks local context and full understanding of the international dimension of financial and business planning requirements; business planning is limited a s result.

A sustainable finance plan is developed approved and implemented for the PA system in both GRL and GKKL landscapes. Business Planning is mandated for four PAs as well as for two adjacent WMAs, along approved best practice guidelines.

TARGET EURO Consult was awarded a consultant by UNDP to develop tourism development and Marketing strategy. The consultant has completed the assignment and the strategy is in place and a final draft was shared and presented before key Tourism stakeholders from the Landscapes. The strategy will be used to inform Finance and Business Plans which will be developed in the financial year 2015/2016.
The project along with other stakeholders, supported development of a video documentary for promoting tourist attractions in Makete District and Njombe region.
Another 30minutes documentary featuring project activities since the start of the project was developed and features on Air through a local TV Star TV

description.narrative: The input of increased HR capacity and funds for equipment following a business planning approach has lead to greater efficiency and effectiveness of park operations in RUNAPA and KINAPA.

comment.narrative: RUNAPA and KNP lack operational capacity to manage park operations in a sustainable manner , gaps exist in HR across park operations, lack of equipment means difficulty to manage fires, poaching and monitoring the ecosystem.

Funds, human resources and equipment are provided and deployed to address threats to RUNAPA and KINAPA in a cost effective manner, utilising business planning - in cooperation with police and judiciary.

A tailor-made course on Open Performance Review and Appraisal Systems (OPRAS) was facilitated for 17 staff from TANAPA, Tanzania Wildlife Division, Tanzania Forest Services and District Councils. Performance appraisal was one of skills gaps identified within the project area.
50 individuals from public and private sectors were trained on customer care as a way of equipping them to participate in effectively in the service and tourism sectors which hold huge potentials in the southern regions of Tanzania.

description.narrative: Stakeholder groups in both RUNAPA and KNP are engaging positively and constructively on biodiversity management

comment.narrative: There is a marked lack of communication largely due to insufficient funding between different PA authorities, local government, communities, civil society and the private sector, causing inefficiencies, misunderstanding and occasional conflict.
A joint (TANAPA-Community-District-Private Sector) stakeholder group formed to address overall intelligence in support of enforcement action both RUNAPA and KNP.

The project further supported conservation education in 8 villages adjacent to GRL in Chamwino (2) and Manyoni (6) districts which was provided collaboratively by the WD Publicity Unit, RUNAPA, Rungwa/Kizigo/Muhesi and relevant officials from the districts. The Law Enforcement Working Group for the GRL managed to coordinate 2 joint patrols. The fair and open process involving demarcation of PAs boundaries is proving success and is enhancing good relations between the PAs and the adjacent communities. This is important especially now that the project is moving towards creating Landscape Coordination Committees which will be charged with overseeing matters related to land and Natural resources in respective landscapes ; including monitoring the operations of the various work groups. In FY 2015/16 Formation of further two working groups on Land use Planning and Ecological and Water Resources Monitoring will be finalized.
MBOMIPA WMA was facilitated by the project to participate in UNDP Equator Initiative were they won a prize award. Two representatives from the association were also facilitated to attend the award ceremony in Nairobi Kenya.
The project budget for FY 2015/16 also has provision for formulating a joint working group for GRL and GKKL specific for Ecological and Water resources Monitoring. The work group shall be guided by a joint work plan.

title.narrative: Mainstream Sustainable Forest Management In the Miombo

description.narrative: Mainstreaming Sustainable Forest Management in the Miombo Woodlands of Western Tanzania.

title.narrative: Final SFM Miombo revised and edidted for Signatures after Feedback Mtg in Feb 2012
Mainstreaming Sustainable Forest Management in the Miombo Woodlands of Western Tanzania (PIMS 3091) Mid-term Review Final Report
Mainstream Sustainable Forest Management In the Miombo
Mainstream Sustainable Forest Management In the Miombo
Mainstream Sustainable Forest Management In the Miombo

description.narrative: Mainstreaming sustainable forest management in the Miombo woodlands of western Tanzania
hill
Environment - policy, planning and administration
Reduction in the rates of deforestation and 30% increase in income of 4,800 households in pilot ares

comment.narrative: Deforestation and degradation resulting form settlers, land clearance and burning for agricultural activities, saw millers, tobacco industry, charcoal producers and climate change currently estimated at 10%

Conduct Project Steering Committee Finalizing the Forest Resource assesment in two districts of Tabora region under the Project Project Midterm Review will be conducted to assess progress towards achievement of the project

Two project boards were conducted as per plan one in February and the other one was done in August. Forest Resource Assessment in two districts completed The Mid-term review was conducted and report was provided with positive observations. Lessons on project design was acknowledged noting comparatively high degree of complexity, ambition, and geographically dispersed activities loaded under the four outcome areas. All these observations were addressed in the management responses and presented to PSC meeting. The lessons will also inform future project design.

description.narrative: Reduction in the rates of deforestation and 30% increase in income of 4,800 households in pilot ares

comment.narrative: Deforestation and degradation resulting form settlers, land clearance and burning for agricultural activities, saw millers, tobacco industry, charcoal producers and climate change currently estimated at 10%

Conduct Project Steering Committee Finalizing the Forest Resource assesment in two districts of Tabora region under the Project Project Midterm Review will be conducted to assess progress towards achievement of the project

Two project boards were conducted as per plan one in February and the other one was done in August. Forest Resource Assessment in two districts completed The Mid-term review was conducted and report was provided with positive observations. Lessons on project design was acknowledged noting comparatively high degree of complexity, ambition, and geographically dispersed activities loaded under the four outcome areas. All these observations were addressed in the management responses and presented to PSC meeting. The lessons will also inform future project design.

description.narrative: To provide land users and managers with the enabling environment (policy, financial, institutional, capacity) for climate resilient SFM adoption in the miombo woodlands

comment.narrative: Currently there is limited mainstreaming of SFM principles into land use in the 133,000 ha of pilot wards; the same applies for the rest of the districts and the region.

By the end of the project, management of 133,000 ha (pilot wards) mainstreaming SFM principles and another 150,000 ha benefiting indirectly from upscaling of lessons through the districts and regional planning and extension structures as well as the SLM project facilitated National Dialogue on SLM/SFM (and the soon to be formulated SLM Investment Framework)

? Guideline of land zoning for sustainable charcoal production through participatory process has been developed by SUA Consultant.
? Charcoal production and consuption value chain study in western Tanzania has been done by Private Consultant from TASONOBI. These two studies are preliminary for Regional charcoal workshop to be held in september, 2015 leading to Sustainable charcoal production,utilization and alternatives as a way to strategy and action plan for the next workshop.
Once a prepared proceeding of the Regional charcoal workshop, lesson will be feed into an international conference on charcoal. This is expected to be held in late 2015. Fifteen (15) villages, five (5) from Mlele and ten (10) from Uyui were involved in the PAME. The area covered was 8,769.64 ha out of 251,170.8 hactares identified on woodlands under CBFM and WMA processes.

Although currently there is about 500 ha of woodlands under CBFM/JFM, none of it is being managed in accordance with the principles of CBFM due to low levels of compliance; so effective baseline is less than a 100ha.

Over 500 ha managed under active CBFM/JFM principles (project pilot area) and another 500 ha impacted by up-scaling during the projects 5 yrs; the additional 500 will benefit through upscaling (using channels explained above)

In the area managed under CBFM permanent boundary marking (clearing and beacons) were done in eight (8) proposed Village Land Forest Reserves (VLFRs) with an area of 2,710.64 hactares. VLFR's are in Kamsisi Village Mlele district (1), Isenga Village,Mbola Village and Isila Village in Uyui district (3),One joint VLFR's bordering Itebulanda,Utenge and Kangeme Village in Urambo district (1) and in Kaliua district (3) to Villages namely Maboha ,Luganjo and Shella. One WMA of ISAWIMA bodering with eleven villages of Kombe,Luganjo,Ussinge,Wachawaseme,Kazanaupate,Limbula,Mtakuja, Mpwaga,Imalampaka,Kamsekwa and Tuombe Mungu in Kaliua district has an area of 159,730.43 hectare with temporarly mark of paints as a process. Declaration procedures is on going under CBFM and WMA processes for the communities to obtain legal ownership of the resources.
Currently estimated to be over 10% per annum[1]; there are several seriously degraded patches of woodlands, particularly the abandoned tobacco fields [1] this figure needs to be confirmed

At least 25% recovery in highly degraded patches and woodlands around the villages as measured by regeneration (recruitment) and improvements in species index and population structure for forests/woodlands

Apart from the area with boundary consolidation under CBFM and WMA there are 26 proposed VLFRs and private/individual forests under CBFM and WMA with temporarly marked by paints to an area of 8,769.64 hectare using GPS out of 251,170.8 hactares estimated in all supported 28 villages of Urambo, Kaliua, Uyui and Mlele districts. Land use planning for zoning of CBFM was conducted in five (5) villages in Uyui district with an area of 21,431 hactares in:
? Isenga Villages land 7,232 ha, VLFR 841ha,grazing 914ha and 387 ha settlement.
? Mbola mashariki Village land 3,136 ha,VLFR 177 ha, grazing land 350 ha and settlement 159 ha.
? Mbola magharibi Village land 2,761 ha, VLFR 154 ha, grazing land 298ha and settlement 159 ha.
? Isila Village land 2,470 ha, VLFR 239 ha, grazing land 152 ha and settlement 59 ha.
? Kasisi Village land 1,558 ha, VLFR 77 ha, grazing land 245 ha and settlement 63 ha.
Establishment of WMA processes was undertaken in 10 Villages of Mlele district which involved collection of baseline information for the proposed Mlele WMA and Certified Village Assembly minutes endorsing WMA were approved in 6 out of 10 Villages. The process is ongoing.
More than 90% of households are below the UN poverty line; however, specific baseline household incomes and number of food secure days will be established during the inception period.

5% increase in household income for 40% of households by year 3, and 30% increase by end of the project; 20% reduction in food insecure days for 40% of households by year 3 and 40% increase by end of the project
Baseline data collection on socio-economic conditions in pilot villages has not been gathered yet, the activity will be incorporated in the 2016 AWP

Currently tobacco curing uses 45m3 per hectare of tobacco instead of 14m3 that can be achieved through improved barns. This is leading to total emissions of about 185,649tons of carbon per year in the 8 pilot villages alone (producing about 8,000 hectares of tobacco. Unsustainably produced charcoal releases a minimum of 9 tons of Carbon; the 10,000 tons of charcoal produced in the wards releases about 90,000 tons of carbon per year.

At least 70% reduction in wood used in tobacco curing for at least 40% of the tobacco cured (on average) leading to direct ERs of 170,368 per year (for ten yrs totalling to 1,703,680tCO2e); further ERs are expected from sustainable charcoal and methane adoption. This will be calculated during the inception period and reported at MTE

As a part of Co funding tobacco companies have promoted the use of improved barns though less than 30% of farmers adopted use of modern barns which consume 10 m3 to 14 m3 of fuelwood per hectare/year.
The RCs delegation from Tabora and Katavi facilitated by the Miombo Project to activate the compliance of the energy efficiency through promotion of modern barns against traditional barns.
? For the afforestation 518,728 ha of tree planted and 5,984 ha of natural regeneration/Ngitiri conservation in the year 2014/2015 in the 4 districts supported by the Project. The effort is collaborative effort among Government, Miombo Project and Tobacco campanies. ? The Project contracted consultant from SUA to undertake an assessment of the factors affecting tree husbandry and set criteria for selecting trees that are suitable either for curing tobacco or charcoal production. In the study 102 tobacco farmers were involved. Then after two days to 62 participants which includes forest extension staffs, tobacco campany representatives and farmesrs from 4 Project districts were done.
? Addition of land use planning in 5 villages as explained above
Coordination between project and tobacco campanies can vividly observed through meetings held twice at ATTT and Miombo Project Office and field visits in afforestation fields and farmers using improved barns. In the meetings we agree on the use of the same VNRCs as the implementers at village levels and have a joint plans of empowering them on natural resources ,environmental conservation issues and energy efficiency. Also we shared experience on how to reserve natural regenerations and agree to follow government procedures of declaration to ensure legal status attained by the communities. We share the report on reservation of natural forests on village land (VLFRs) and tree planting so to avoid duplication of effort in the same area and know the extent of co funding.

description.narrative: Policy and institutional support

comment.narrative: All policy statements mention importance of SFM but dont have details of how SFM will be ensured
At least 3 policies revised to mainstream SFM principles and so provide a better policy environment for SFM;

4 policies on regulatory frame work and institutional arrangements to support SFM in the Miombo woodland were reviewed and submitted by the Consultant. These includes forestry, wildlife, livestock and agriculture.
Policy implementation very weak due to weak judiciary and inadequate understanding of, and buy-in for the policies by local communities

Legislation and institutional arrangement guiding policy implementation for at least 3 key policies are influenced by project results and overtly recognize SFM principles; Local level governance of SFM improved by incorporation of traditional regulations into bye laws with clear implementation mechanisms; At least a 100% increase in number of people reporting to be aware of the NRM/ SFM/ CBFM polices and bye laws; At least a 100% increase in number of people actively abiding by the NRM/ SFM/ CBFM polices and bye laws;

32 VNRCs with 384 members trained on their role responsibilities and participatory resource governance. The out come of the surveillance done by VNRCs in the proposed Village Land
Forest Reserves (VLFRs) are as follows: ? Culprits found illegally with 4 logs of Pterocarpus sp in the VLFR then punished by charging fine of 50,000/=Tsh and logs, saws and 2 bicycles
were confiscated by VNRC's and Village government using bylaws in Kaliua district.
? One lorry with fuel wood valued 2,600,000/= Tsh, was confiscated by VNRCs in Uyui district .
? 2 groups of livestock found encroaching the VLFRs in Mlele district charged fine of 50,000/= Tshs, after declared guilt against Village bylaws
? In Urambo district VNRCs confiscated 26 logs of Brachystegia spp (Miombo trees), the value is equivalent to 1,168,000.00 Tshs when sold.
Also positive indication of recovery of flora (regeneration) and fauna (small wild animals) noted in the proposed VLFRs. Amended Village by laws have been forwarded by district councils to TAMISEMI for approval so as the execution of VNRCs legally done to safeguard SFM.

description.narrative: Strengthening skills and capacities for knowledge based CBFM/JFM, integrated soil fertility management and land use planning

comment.narrative: Although currently there is about 500 hectares of land declared to be under CBFM/JFM, none of it being managed in accordance to the principles of CBFM in practice; thus the effective baseline is less than 100

By the end of the project, at least 500 ha of woodlands being managed under functional[1] CBFM/JFM [1]The participatory M&E system to be defined under outcome 2 will refine this indicator and test practical ways to monitor it.

Participatory Monitoring and Evaluation (PAME) is ongoing to the marked area of 8,769.64 hectares out of 251,170.8 hectares etimated in the woodlands under CBFM and WMA, apart from the consolidated area in the processes.

The two regions (Tabora, Rukwa) have line ministry technical staff with training in forestry, agriculture, energy and trade. However, few staff members have integrated the technical skills to adequately support SFM by land users. A very small percentage of the land users have received training form the baseline projects described in the GEF incremental section; exact baselines will be established during the training needs assessment (at inception)

By year 2, at least 50% of the technical officers and land users requiring capacity improvement have received skills (training and materials) to enhance their capacity for integrated soil fertility management, CBFM/JFM and adaptation to climate change

194 farmers and 32 technical were trained on intergrated soil fertility management which resulted to the 1164 farmers involved in new agricultural practices in the 4 districts of Uyui, Kaliua, Urambo and Mlele. Generally, maize yields have increased from 4 to 18 bags as the result of spill over effects.
Participatory action research lead by SUA and ARI (Agriculturall Reserch Institute) Tumbi -Tabora researchers which involves 20 farmers(12 Female and 8 Male) from Urambo and Mlele. The effect of Inorganic fertilizer application on maize grain yield during this report for the 4 treatments are:
? Farmers practices 693kg/ha (6.9 bags)
? Manure+ Sulfan 1734 kg/ha (17.3bags)
? YaraMira Cereal +Sulfan 1627kg/ha (16.3 bags)
? Minjingu Phosphate + Calcium Nitrate 1039 kg/ha (10.4 bags)
This shows positive results particularly the active participation of farmers and the field results which indicate that conservation agriculture in combination with integrated soil fertility management has a potential for increasing maize production despite the experienced drought prone cropping season in the Miombo Project area in the study area for the season of 2014/2015.
This baseline will be established through the participatory M&E system to be formulated under outcome 2.5 and reported in the PIRs
At leaset 25% increase over the baseline (by the end of the project)

The Partcipatory Monitoring and Evaluation System (PAME) is being implemented in Uyui, Mlele and Kaliua Districts. The objective is to empower and enable local communities to identify their own needs and objectives and determine which environmental and socio-economic elements, activities and processes to keep a continuous track of, in order to determine whether progress is being made in achieving their desired goals and objectives in line with project goal. A total of 556 (374M, 182F) participants attended the training. The training session was participatory and encouraged knowledge exchange between the trainer of trainers and local communities. 97% of them confirmed through the training evaluation that the sessions were relevant and useful.
Currently less than 10%
At least 50% increase in number of farmers consistently applying 3-5 integrated soil fertility management practices

226 selected farmers, Ward Agricultural Extension Officers, District Agricultural Extension Officers from 4 districts were trained on integrated soil fertility management through participatory action research, conservation agriculture and agro-forestry technologies.
As a result of the training 1164 farmers were involved in new agricultural practices in the 4 districts (i.e. Uyui 343, Mlele 281, Urambo 272 and Kaliua 268). The out come as indicated from the participatory research above.

Maize yields currently at less than a third of potential (5tons/ha versus 15tons/ha). Baseline yields for other indicator crops will be established as soon as these are selected per village (at inception)

At least 25% increase in agricultural produce for key crops as a result of improved integrated soil fertility management and other agricultural practices (which increase soil fertility and soil-water use by crops
Generally, maize yields have increased from 4 to 18 bags that is 14 bags per hactare as an increase. This results from 226 trainees explained above and will be sustained based on the research done.
Currently 95% of tobacco grown by small scale farmers using inefficient traditional kilns that consume 45m3 of wood per ton of tobacco instead of the 14 m3/tons for improved barns;
At least 40% adoption of improved tobacco barns in pilot villages and an additional 30% in neighbouring villages leading direct ERs of 1.7 million tCO2e (see calculations in the GEB section)

Tobacco companies reported low rate ( about 25%) of farmers adopted use of improved barns which consume 10 m3 to 14 m3 of fuelwood per hectare/year. In comparison to traditional barns which use 45 m3. Based on that fact Miombo supported Regional Commissional delegation to make follow up and enforce the compliance to energy efficiency and environmental issues as whole.
Currently less than 10% due to mistrust of the weather information and inadequate dissemination of same
At least 25% increase in number of farmers using weather information for decision making (co-fin);
A total of 1570 farmers (Uyui 514, Kaliua 374, Mlele 432 and Urambo 250) received weather information through cell phone and used for decision making on agricultural activities.

description.narrative: Adoption of Sustainable charcoal and energy switch reduce pressure on woodlands

comment.narrative: Currently none
At least 10 charcoal associations are active and facilitating their members to adopt and comply with sustainable charcoal principles by the end of the project (half that by year 3).

The Project facilitated the study visit of 4 Foresters from Kaliua, Urambo, Uyui and Mlele to Kilosa Sustainable charcoal Project. The objective of the study visits was to learn more on how to address sustainable charcoal production.
Based on the experience from the study visit 2 groups from Uyui and Urambo were formed, trained in collaboration with TaTEDO and now in the practice of sustainable charcoal production.
The spill over will increase after the charcoal workshop to be held in July,2015 which will produce the stategy of sustainable charcoal production.
Pilot villages producing an average of 10,000 tons of charcoal per year using largely traditional and inefficient methods

By the end of the project, more than 40% of charcaol being produced via sustainable means, saving upto to 20% of wood needed to make the wood (the ERs to be derived from this savings will be reported at MTE).)

Introduction of 4 briquette machines installed to centres of Urambo, Kaliua,Uyui and Katavi Region as an alternative source of charcoal. The capacity of producing briquettes is 1440 tone/year for the 4 machines. This technology will lead to saving of 14.4% charcoal produced using traditional kiln in the pilot villages.
A total of 398 improved cooking stoves scaled up in 4 districts where as 100 are in Kaliua, 92 Urambo, 12 Mlele and 194 Uyui district. This reveal the reduction of the fuel wood (i.e.fire wood and charcoal) by 75 % in comparison with traditional stoves as per wood consumption survey done by DFTs from Urambo and Kaliua which is ongoing to other districts.
Currently no specific institution to coordinate charcoal processes, responsibilities spread across a number of ministries with no specific coordination
By year 3, an institution to support regional level charcoal coordination in place and functioning; discussions for national replication started by the end of the project
No progress yet
Many public institutions use electricity, LPG or wood. The specific baseline for those using methane gas from human waste will be established during the inception, but it is likely to be less than 4
At least 4 public institutions adopt methane generated from human waste for cooking;

Management of the 2 biolatrine in Milambo and Tabora Girls Secondary schools adopted methane generated from human waste for cooking and light to ensure energy efficiency. The result of this construction serves about 480 m3/year and 964m3/year of wood for Tabora girls and Milambo secondary and significantly offset carbon dioxide and reduce deforestation. The technology is planned to be implemented in Inyonga Secondary school Mlele district.

description.narrative: Markets and technology support expansion of livelihood options in miombo woodlands to reduce pressure on agriculture and natural resources and increase income

comment.narrative: Limited opportunities for markets due to very few agro processing businesses, hence agricultural produce difficult to market
At least 2 agri-processing business established and making contribution to local economic development and SFM

Two agroprocessing businesses have been established and supported in Uyui and Urambo district viz: In Uyui, farmers have been engaged in processing the wild fruits from miombo woodlands to generate and increase the income. The end products from the wild fruits includes jam, wine, medicinal powders and jelly, mango pickels,dried vegetable and mushrooms.
2000 jars of Gogondi Pythus engliriana medicinal powder were sold to earn an amount of 10,000,000 Tsh (2000 jars X5000 tsh) by Membo women group in Mbola village. 90 liters of honey sold to earn 630,000 tsh ( 90 Lts X 7000), jams and wine 306,500 tshs as per the reporting time period. The sunflowers oil processing centre established in Nsenda village by Urambo district council accommodated farmers supported by Miombo project with sunflower seeds as an alternative to cash crop instead of farmers relying only on tobacco as a cash crop. This is a value chain activity. 6588 liters of sunflower oil were produced in Urambo district from the farmers supported by the project and the amount earned is 18,446,400 tsh for 90 farmers. 491,1150 tsh earned through maize milling machine fees and the total of tsh 392,819 by selling maize flours in Uyui district. Market linkage was facilitated to wild fruits proccessors through exhibitions and participatory market survey in Tabora and Katavi. Gogondi medicinal powders produced in Tabora can now be accessed in Katavi region.
The process for supporting compliance with certification requirements for NTFPs is an ongoing activity. Three groups have acquired Tax Identification Number, Bar Codes and solar driers which will increase the quality of production and expand the marketing opportunities. Two processing centres for honey in Urambo and wild fruits in Uyui will be supported towards TBS & TFDA Certifications (Tanzania Bureau of Standards & Tanzania Food and Drugs Authority). TBS, TFDA and Barcodes will lead to the expansion of market NTFPs to increase the volume of trade in SFM/BD friendly income generating products in the project area

There is currently some trading in NTFPs but the volumes vary from village to village. Exact baselines on volumes of trade will be established during the inception, but it is expected to be quite low.
By the end of the project, volume of trade in SFM/BD friendly income generating products increased by at least 50% from the currently low baseline.

The project has contracted a consultant from SUA to undertake a market survey to identify regular and niche markets for NTFPs from Miombo woodlands. This activity will be done in July,2015. It is expected to increase the volume of NTFPs as aresult of this survey through proposed and established market linkages between identified markets and specialized producers.
Tobacco farmers currently accessing credit but only for the cash crop (tobacco). Generally less than 25% of farmers have access to micro-finance and credits outside of the tobacco context
At least 35% increase in number of farmers accessing micro-finance and credits for food crops by the end of the project;

Seven groups (7) have been identified in Mlele, Urambo and Kaliua districts to implement the village savings and loan model. These groups comprising from 15 to 20 people will be offering loans and micro credits to group members to finance agribusinesses activities. The first phase will include six villages (Kaulolo, Inyonga, Nsenkwa, Kamsisi, Imalamakoye and Usinge) then scale up to other project villages
Currently the only cooperatives relate to tobacco farming and marketing
At least 3 non-tobacco cooperatives established and facilitating operations for production of other crops (depending on needs identified during project inception)

One non tobacco Cooperative society for Agricultural Marketing has been formed in Kaliua district Tabora region with 181 members (151 male and 30 female) The cooperative will concentrate on bulking of farmers products for marketing as well as inputs supply. The crops intedend are maize, sunflowers, rice, groundnuts, beans, cassava and sesame.
The project facilitated 134 cooperative members (111 male and 23 female) with training on how agricultural cooperative is operated and managed.
Training resulted in members electing cooperative board members, as well as setting the entrance fees and shares, rules and regulations for the cooperative were also developed.
The proposed name is UKOLUSHIMA AM-SFMCOS ( Usinge, Kombe, Luganjo, Shela, Maboha Agricultural Marketing-Sustainable Forest Management Cooperative Society) and one share is 10,0000 value each member to purchase 3, which will total 30,000. The entrance fee is 5000, So far the contributions from Cooperative members is 1,350,000 tsh. Rules and regulations for the AMCOs set was also approved.

title.narrative: Climate Information & Early Warning Systems in Tanzania

description.narrative: Climate Information & Early Warning Systems in Tanzania.

title.narrative: Stregthening climate information and early warning systems in Tanzania for climate resilient development and adaptation to climate change projects - Mid-Term Review
Strengthening Climate information and Early Warning Systems in Tanzania for Climate Resilient Development and Adaptation to Climate Change Project Mid-term Review
Climate Information & Early Warning Systems in Tanzania
Climate Information & Early Warning Systems in Tanzania

description.narrative: The objective of the project is to strengthen the weather, climate and hydrological monitoring capabilities, early warning systems and available information for responding to extreme weather and planning adaptation to climate change in Tanzania.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
To strengthen the climate monitoring capabilities, early warning systems and available information for responding to climate shocks and planning adaptation to climate change in Tanzania.
Level of capacity of agencies to monitor, assess and disseminate hydro-climate information for early warnings and long-term planning

comment.narrative: The aggregate average level of capacity as per the Capacity Assessment Score is measured at 2.24 at the start of project.
The aggregate average Capacity Assessment Score at end of project is 3.5

Completed procurement of 16 AWS
Completing siting and installation of 16 new stations
Completed procurement of servers for additional data storage and transmission (2 server TMA)
Completed procurement of new hydrological equipment
Completed siting and installation of the new hydrological equipment The Pangani Basin Water Board has received 10 water level loggers with pressure transducer sensors, 10 remote data transfer (telemetry) systems via GSM/SMS, 5 automatic rainfall stations and 2 field computers (RPDA). The equipment has been installed. The Ruvuma and Southern Coast Basins Water Boards have received 5 hydrological stations, 40 river gauges and 10 rain gauges. The equipment has been installed. The project continued building capacity on the application of new technologies.
8 instrumentation specialists from TMA and the Ministry of Water have been trained on the operation of the newly supplied AWS.
14 hydrologists from the Pangani and Ruvuma Basins have received on-site practical training on the installation of the hydrological equipment.
20 government staff from implementing partners have participated in different international workshops funded by the CIRDA programme from February 2014 to 30 June 2015. These workshops built capacity on the application of various technologies, which aim to improve the collection and processing of data and the identification of opportunities for engagement with the private sector to generate revenue and render sustainable the weather services. All these efforts contributed to the improvement of weather services and have informed the process of cost recovery in the country.
273 community representatives from Liwale and Arumeru districts have been trained on the application of climate information products to mitigate/ cope with droughts and floods.

description.narrative: Enhanced Capacity of TMA and Water Basins to monitor (and forecast) droughts and floods.
% of national coverage by climate monitoring system Frequency of data transmission and reception of current weather and river levels in TMA and the WBAs

comment.narrative: 50% of the territory is covered by some form of monitoring, but only 30% by AWS. River stations are read manually every 2 hours during rainfall but transmitted at various frequencies depending on the observers capacity, automatic river gauges transmit every 30 minutes. TMA network operates at various frequencies, with most rapid transmission being hourly from AWS and slowest being daily manual readings transmitted on a weekly basis.

75% of national territory is covered by an automated network Data from river stations transmitted every three hours to TMA, every 30 minutes to the WBAs; Data from automatic weather stations received by TMA every three hours basis and from manual stations on a daily basis

A technical working group (composed of technical teams from Tanzania Meteorological Agency (TMA), Ministry of Water (MoW), Ministry of Agriculture Food Security and Cooperatives, Prime Ministers Office Disaster Management Department, Pangani Basin Water Board, and Ruvuma and Southern Coast Water Board) was established and became operational. The team is discussing various protocols which will enable data sharing and show how end users can benefit from weather services.
Establishing integrated database of climate/hydro information that will be accessed by sectoral users in real time.
Completing mapping of the current weather stations in Tanzania
Finalising study to assess efficiency of available explicit and implicit operating procedures and draw lessons from other available guidelines
Developing Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) for droughts and floods in consultation with all partners at the national and local levels, including NGOs Indicator 1: The target of the project is to add 36 automatic weather stations, of which 16 have already been installed. In collaboration with TMA, the project is now at the final stages of procuring the rest of the new 20 AWS. The equipment will be delivered and installed by the end of 2016. Moreover, to date, the project has also procured 10 hydrological stations, 50 river gauges and 20 automatic rainfall gauges, which have been installed in the Pangani and Ruvuma Basins. Under the guidance of UNDP, the procurement of the remaining 10 hydrological stations, 60 river gauges and 20 automatic rainfall gauges has been initiated. Procurement is underway and the equipment will be delivered in 2016. Overall, the installation of the hydro-met equipment has expanded the hydro-meteorological automated network to 62% of the national territory. The project is on track to meet the target of 75% by the end of 2015. Indicator 2: The project has just completed phase one of installing the hydro-met equipment. Data from river stations has started flowing in to the Pangani River Basin headquarters as of July 2015. The TMA is planning to start using the data received from the newly installed AWS in October 2015, after installation is finalized and in compliance with WMO standards. 2 field laptops and 2 servers have been procured and delivered to TMA for the calibration of the AWS and for the storage and transmission of data, respectively. The project has initiated the process of designing an integrated database, which will accommodate both climate and hydro data. This will strengthen the capacity of key stakeholders to generate and access relevant climate information and also make the data available to end users.The project will make it possible that all the stations are linked and data is transmitted to the TMA network. This will improve data quality and weather forecasts. Working on the country strategy to harmonize data collection with the WMO standards. The project is also supporting data rescuing and digitization to make available historical data from all ministries to the 2 pilot districts.

description.narrative: Efficient and effective use of hydro-meteorological and environmental information for making early warnings and long-term development plans.

Percent of population with access to improved climate information and improved flood and drought warnings % of which are women Type of development planning framework informed by climate information in Meru and Liwale Districts

comment.narrative: 30% of people in the project sites have access to some climate information, but no people in the project sites have access to improved climate information, drought or early warnings. TAFSIP, MKUKUTA II, and other high level frameworks include climate change and mitigating measures but no plans at local level

At least 70% of residents in the targeted areas benefit from improved climate information, drought or early warnings Local land use plans and development plans in Meru and Liwale include climate change risk information

Indicator 1:
Finalized feasibility study on the setup of a 24-hour emergency operation centre (EOC) within the Prime Ministers Office - Disaster Management Department (PMO-DMD). The study includes background information on the management of the EOC, its functions and structure and personnel requirements, the required technical expertise and equipment, communication equipment, criteria for site selection, possibilities to engage with the private sector for long-term sustainability, list of agencies/stakeholders including their roles and estimated budget. The EoC will be a central command and control facility responsible for carrying out the principles of emergency preparedness and management in the country.
Mobilizing local disaster-management committees and CBOs to participate in the simulation exercise and crowdsourcing through consultations and training.
Facilitating field visits and stakeholder consultations to understand how users of early warning advisories use the information for managing climate and weather-related risks and how their decision frameworks affect the interpretations of advisories and warnings.
The project commissioned a study to assess the efficiency of the available explicit and implicit operating procedures for issuing early warnings. The study provided background information on the status of the Tanzania Emergency and Preparedness Plan and a basis for the development of Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for droughts and floods. The SOPs will highlight each partners roles and responsibilities, the types of early warning messages, the appropriate responses, the resources and communication pathways to reach local communities. The project has initiated the process of developing the SOPs. The 1st draft for the Liwale district is done and it focuses on the processes to be undertaken by all stakeholders in their efforts to mitigate/cope with floods and droughts. Indicators 1 and 2:
Trained 273 and 157 community representatives from the Liwale and Arumeru district, respectively. The 273 community representatives were trained as trainers for trainers. The trainers were given the responsibility to disseminate their knowledge and skills to their fellow village members. The training sessions focused on the use of climate information to overcome droughts and floods and on the downscaling of climate information at the local level. More than 70% of the community members of the targeted villages will be exposed to the improved knowledge. Ultimately, its application to the development of village plans will contribute to the development of district development plans. The training was extended to 30 district sector heads of the Liwale district and 28 sector heads of the Arumeru district.

description.narrative: (i) Robust M&E and Management Information System for the Productive Social Safety Nets (PSSN) (ii) NSPF and PSSN indicators incorporated into NBS national, thematic and panel survey instruments (iii) National Social Protection Framework (NSPF) in place (iv) National Social Protection Framework M&E and Implementation Plan developed

comment.narrative: (i) Weak M&E and Management Information System for the Productive Social Safety Nets (PSSN) (ii) Limited inclusion of social protection indicators in National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) national, thematic and panel survey instruments (iii) No National Social Protection Framework (NSPF) in place (iv) National Social Protection Framework M&E and Implementation Plan developed

- Social protection indicators included in National Pannel Survey - Development process of NSPF implementation plan and M&E framework initiated - Poverty Monitoring Master Plan (PMMP) with social protection indicators developed

- Draft National Panel Survey with social protection indicators developed and stakeholder consultations planned for early 2017. - Development of NSPF implementation plan and M&E framework initiated, which will be completed by February 2017. - Development of Poverty Monitoring Master Plan (PMMP) initiated with key social protection indicators identified
